description: A fear-mongering article was based on misleading and cherry-picked data about the number of churches and mosques in London.
title: Did London Close 500 Churches and Open 423 New Mosques?

description: The fast food chain is celebrating International Women's Day by turning its iconic golden arches into a "W."
title: Are McDonald’s Restaurants Flipping Their Iconic Golden Arches Upside Down for Women’s Day?

description: An image showing the comedian and television host next to a possibly armed guard is real, but the photograph was not taken at an anti-gun rally.
title: Was Ellen DeGeneres Surrounded by Armed Guards at an Anti-Gun Rally?

description: Some fringe blogs in North America picked up a claim about the Guarani Aquifer that has already been debunked by Brazilian journalists.
title: Are Nestle and Coca-Cola Trying to Privatize a South American Aquifer?

description: An image of an elephant standing near a tram in London is frequently shared with a fictional backstory about English twin gangsters Ronnie and Reggie Kray.
title: Did the Kray Twins Use an Elephant to Rob a London Tram?

description: Dubious right-wing blogs misrepresented an encounter prompted by Washington state's "red flag" law.
title: Did Seattle Police Confiscate a Man’s Guns Without a Warrant?

description: In February 2018, Amazon Alexa owners began claiming that the devices were randomly broadcasting an unwanted "creepy laugh."
title: Is Amazon’s Alexa Creepily Laughing for No Apparent Reason?

description: A meme featuring a quote from the former Minnesota congresswoman is a hoax.
title: Did Michele Bachmann Say That ‘Jesus Created Assault Rifles’?

description: A gory image of a child who had been attacked by a dog was stolen and used by propagandists to spread fear about "white genocide" in South Africa.
title: Did a Little Girl Have a ‘Joker Smile’ Carved Into Her Face in South Africa?

description: A web site that publishes viral content accurately recounts the terrible story of Katie Flynn's death in 2005.
title: Was a Young Girl Decapitated By a Seat Belt in a Car Crash?

description: A headline on the conspiracy blog Infowars.com mischaracterizes a tweet by a legitimate news reporter.
title: Did a First Responder Say He Was Told to ‘Stand Down’ in Parkland?

description: An article appearing to report that the president has an unorthodox idea for ending mass shootings at schools appeared on a page that only publishes satire.
title: Does President Donald Trump Plan to End School Shootings — By Banning Schools?

description: A constellation of fake news sites claimed Joy Behar was fired from "The View," but the headlines and content don't match.
title: Did ABC Fire Joy Behar from ‘The View’?

description: A meme suggesting that Melania Trump plagiarized her Women's History Month statement from Michelle Obama is based on paraphrased and inaccurate quotes.
title: Did Melania Trump Plagiarize Michelle Obama’s Statement on Women’s History Month?

description: Yee pleaded guilty to arms trafficking in 2016.
title: Was Ex-California State Senator and Gun Control Advocate Leland Yee Arrested for Gun Trafficking?

description: A questionable, undated blog reported the recall as "fresh" — ignoring the fact that it was issued in 2017.
title: Did Target Issue an Easter Egg Recall?

description: Web sites mischaracterized the governor's order instructing state police to disarm individuals demonstrably at risk for violence.
title: Did Rhode Island’s Governor Sign an Executive Order to Seize Guns?

description: A recent fake news item sought to distort the results of an inquiry into sexual abuse in the Catholic Church in Australia.
title: Did Pope Francis Forgive 4,444 Pedophile Priests in Australia?

description: The billionaire investor and sometime Trump regulatory reform adviser insists he had no prior knowledge of President Trump's tariff announcement.
title: Did Former Trump Adviser Carl Icahn Dump Millions in Stock Before Steel Tariffs Were Announced?

description: A Georgia senator has claimed — without any supporting evidence — that Delta offers discounts on air travel to Planned Parenthood members.
title: Does Delta Airlines Give Planned Parenthood Members Discounted Rates?

description: A disreputable web site falsely claimed that the "vice president of Pfizer" said a vaccine for human papillomavirus is "deadly."
title: Did Pfizer’s Vice President ‘Blow the Whistle’ on Gardasil?

description: After news reports revealed the purchase amid proposed funding cuts, the HUD secretary said he wants to cancel it.
title: Did Ben Carson Purchase a $31,000 Dining Set and Charge It to HUD?

description: A new variant of a years-old rumor about a worker adding HIV-infected blood to foods or beverages takes aim at a popular brand of butter.
title: Is Anchor Butter Contaminated with HIV?

description: An image that appeared to be a luckily timed photograph was actually created with digital manipulation software.
title: Is This a Jumping Baby Elephant?

description: Mack Beggs's request to compete in the boys' division was stymied by Texas state officials.
title: Did a Transgender Teen Boy Win a Girls’ State Wrestling Title?

description: The ceremony was held by an offshoot of the notorious Unification Church.
title: Did Hundreds of Worshipers Attend an AR-15 Blessing Ceremony at a Church?

description: A fabricated article about the movie mogul's supposed self-inflicted death appeared on an irksome fake news web site.
title: Did Harvey Weinstein Commit Suicide in Arizona?

description: The news media organization reportedly invested in mechanical assistance to help their journalists and news anchors spin the news before publication.
title: Did CNN Purchase an Industrial-Sized Washing Machine to Spin News?

description: A Vibrant Body Company bra promotion has been linked to rumors of a human trafficking scheme.
title: Is a Vibrant Bra Promotion a Criminal Scam?

description: A fake tweet was spread in an attempt to smear the reputation of David Hogg, who survived a mass shooting at his high school that left seventeen people dead.
title: Did a Parkland Survivor Tweet a Homophobic Slur?

description: In the not-so-distant past, white carnival goers threw eggs or balls at African Americans in a game popularly known as "Hit the Nigger Baby."
title: Was a Violently Racist Carnival Game Once Popular in America?

description: Reports about a 2011 change to Iowa's gun licensing rules in Iowa went viral after a mass school shooting in 2018.
title: Does Iowa Grant Gun Permits to Blind People?

description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid are not calling senior citizens and asking for personal information ahead of the launch of a new Medicare card.
title: New Medicare Card Telephone Scam

description: A tweet posted in 2010 by NRA spokeswoman Dana Loesch about a fired CNN reporter was criticized several years later as anti-Semitic.
title: Did the NRA’s Dana Loesch Tweet That CNN’s Rick Sanchez Was ‘Fired by a Jew?’

description: Two fake quotes ostensibly uttered by the Florida senator resurfaced in the aftermath of the February 2018 mass school shooting in his state.
title: Does Marco Rubio Want to Give Felons Right to Own Guns, But Not to Vote?

description: Social media posts inaccurately claim that the formulation of Suave Professionals brand products causes hair loss.
title: Does Suave Shampoo Contain an Ingredient That Causes Hair Loss?

description: The claim that the Senate Minority Leader has a concealed weapons permit is based on one single unsourced article.
title: Does Chuck Schumer Have an Unrestricted Concealed Carry Permit?

description: The comings and goings of the Trump administration's White House staff may seem like a revolving door, but First Daughter Ivanka Trump hasn't yet been shown the exit.
title: Was Ivanka Trump Fired from the White House?

description: Viral warnings about "extreme hackers" stealing information via popular entertainment apps on Facebook are false and misleading.
title: Are Hackers Stealing Private Information via ‘What Would You Look Like Bald’ Facebook Apps?

description: Election officials rejected the possibility that CityKey cards could cause an upswing in voter fraud.
title: Does Chicago’s Identification Card Program Allow Undocumented Immigrants to Vote?

description: As usual. satire is mistaken for reality when it reflects something the reading audience fears will be happening.
title: Is the Military Drawing Up Plans for Nationwide Gun Confiscations?

description: A 1974 report co-authored by Ruth Bader Ginsburg about sex bias in U.S. law has been grossly misinterpreted.
title: Did Ruth Bader Ginsburg Say that Pedophilia Was Good for Children?

description: A law barring the open carry of loaded firearms was passed in 1967 with the support of the National Rifle Association, after armed Black Panthers "invaded" the California state capitol earlier that year.
title: Did the NRA Support a 1967 ‘Open Carry’ Ban in California?

description: The group didn't formally give the U.S. president that label, but it used strong language in accusing him of human rights breaches.
title: Did Amnesty International ‘Officially Declare’ Donald Trump a ‘Human Rights Violator’?

description: A fabricated quote attributed to Tariq Ramadan has once again gained attention on the internet after the academic was arrested on rape charges.
title: Did a Muslim Scholar Advocate ‘Colonizing’ U.S. and Canada with Sharia Law?

description: A fake news web site used a photograph of a white nationalist to spruce up another of their fabricated stories.
title: Did a Gay Man ‘Turn Heterosexual’ After a Near-Death Experience?

description: Viral stories rehash a legal tussle between Pepsi and the Center for Environmental Health, but they mischaracterize that battle’s outcome.
title: Did Pepsi ‘Admit’ Their Sodas Contain Cancer-Causing Ingredients?

description: A 1991 article reported that Trump stopped an assault in New York City shortly after his own mother had been mugged, but corroborating details are murky.
title: Did Donald Trump Stop a Mugging in 1991?

description: Several web sites mischaracterized an October 2017 California law preventing school personnel from carrying guns on campus.
title: Did California’s Governor Ban Teachers from Shooting Back at School Shooters?

description: School walkouts and a protest in Washington, D.C. are being planned in response to a deadly February 2018 school shooting in Florida.
title: Is a School Walkout Planned in Response to the Parkland Mass Shooting?

description: After preacher Billy Graham died, a meme appeared attaching him to an offensive quote.
title: Did Billy Graham Say ‘All Homosexuals Should Be Castrated’?

description: U.S. calendars for 2018 on Apple devices initially did not mark Easter, but the holiday has since been restored to calendar apps.
title: Did Apple Remove Easter from iOS Calendars?

description: President Obama hasn't announced he's seeking an international position he likely couldn't obtain in any case.
title: Did Barack Obama Announce a Bid to Become UN Secretary General?

description: A Facebook meme gets the basic facts right about the gun lobby's status as a social welfare organization.
title: Is the NRA a Tax-Exempt Nonprofit Organization?

description: Rumors that a worker at Cadbury plant was arrested for contaminating the company's products with HIV-infected blood are a variant of an old and false rumor.
title: Are Cadbury Products Contaminated with HIV?

description: A quote attributed to Wayne LaPierre of the NRA is abbreviated in a slightly misleading fashion.
title: Did Wayne LaPierre Say There Should Be ‘No Guns in Schools, Period’?

description: An image purportedly showing famed astronomer Carl Sagan holding a sign reading "No Billboards in Space" is fake.
title: Is This Carl Sagan Holding a ‘No Billboards in Space’ Sign?

description: A story about a high school student talking his way into showering with girls after gym class is a work of fiction.
title: Was a Student Suspended for Pretending to be Transgender to Use the Girls’ Locker Room?

description: The environmental activist, journalist, and suffragette encouraged people to "be a nuisance" and to "never give up"  — even if discouraged by bad politics.
title: Marjory Stoneman Douglas Quote About Activism?

description: A conspiracy theory accusing Nick and Laura Phelps of being "crisis actors" received a new (and false) twist in the aftermath of the Parkland, Florida school shooting.
title: Is Laura Phelps a Crisis Actor Who Lost a Child at Both Sandy Hook and Marjory Stoneman Douglas?

description: Donald Trump filed a trademark application for his campaign slogan in November 2012, despite claims that he had no plans to run for office at the time.
title: Did Donald Trump Register ‘Make America Great Again’ in 2012?

description: Days after a customer's account spread on social media, the company warned about a product defect affecting specific models.
title: Are Some Instant Pot Cookers Having Meltdowns?

description: A satirical web site played on allegations of racial profiling by the bureau for a humorous story about the hit Marvel movie.
title: Was The Cast of ‘Black Panther’ Added to FBI Watch List?

description: A viral cartoon accurately presents several quotations by the then-presidential candidate, delivered on the campaign trail in 2015 and 2016.
title: Did Donald Trump Encourage Violence at His Rallies?

description: A very small minority of Twitter users expressed a critical view of Andrew Pollack, but none appear to have addressed their comments directly to him.
title: Did People ‘Attack’ the Father of a School Shooting Victim for Wearing a Donald Trump T-Shirt?

description: There are almost no circumstances under which someone can sue a manufacturer in civil court for a crime committed with a gun.
title: Gun Manufacturers Can’t Be Sued For Crimes Committed With Their Products?

description: The National Rifle Association's letters to Wisconsin judicial candidates came under scrutiny in the wake of a mass school shooting in February 2018.
title: Did the NRA Ask Judicial Candidates for ‘Position Letters’ on Guns?

description: A photograph showing President Trump holding notes during the listening session with survivors of the Parkland, Florida, school shooting is genuine.
title: Did Trump Use ‘Crib Notes’ During Listening Session with Parkland Survivors?

description: According to the First Lady's spokesperson, widely shared reports that she demanded a White House exorcism are "not true in any way."
title: Did Melania Trump Hire an Exorcist to Cleanse the White House of Obama ‘Demons’?

description: A set of images showing President Barack Obama and President Donald Trump in the aftermath of different school shootings are real, but they do not necessarily tell the entire story.

description: A parody account tricked Twitter users with a darkly comic video about a fictional mix-up.
title: Did Make-a-Wish Apologize for Sending the Wrong Drake to Visit a Terminally Ill Boy?

description: The network denied Colton Haab's allegation that it asked him to write a speech for a town hall meeting about gun safety.
title: Did CNN Give a Parkland Shooting Survivor Scripted Questions?

description: An image purportedly showing a large shark on a Kitty Hawk beach is a composite of at least two different photographs.
title: Did a Huge Shark Wash Up on a North Carolina Beach?

description: Dubious web sites have used students' purportedly conflicting accounts of a Florida mass shooting to suggest a nefarious conspiracy.
title: Eyewitness Testimony Confirms a Second Parkland Shooter?

description: There is no evidence to date that the confessed school shooter belongs to any organized hate group, although he reportedly expressed white supremacist views online.

description: A meme used a fabricated quote based on Lahren's comments about politicians' offering thoughts and prayers to mass shooting victims.

description: An impostor Twitter account posing as Rep. Maxine Waters posted an inflammatory remark with the hashtag #guncontrolnow.

description: A prank Facebook post, and old reports about a drug overdose, fueled unfounded rumors about the rapper's demise.

description: The Metallica vocalist was falsely identified in a photograph amid 2014 protests over his involvement with a History Channel show.
title: Is This James Hetfield Standing Near a Bear He Killed?

description: After a massacre at Dunblane Primary School in 1996, there have been no school shootings in the UK.

description: Online trolls tried to push claims of violence, but they were quickly foiled by others on social media.

description: A glitch that affects the time stamps on Google searches has led to bogus "false flag" conspiracy theories — again.

description: According to popular lore, an assortment of United States presidents from John Quincy Adams to Herbert Hoover shared space in the West Wing with giant reptiles.

description: A meme going around is heavy on propaganda and embarrassingly light on fact.
title: Was Snopes.com ‘BUSTED’ for Our CEO’s Ties to George Soros?

description: A newspaper editorial gets some facts right, and some wrong, in weighing up the consequences of Colorado's legalization of recreational marijuana.

description: In the wake of a school shooting that left 17 people dead in Florida, trolls attempted to stir up division by falsely claiming that the shooter had been photographed wearing a pro-Communist t-shirt.

description: In the immediate aftermath of a mass shooting on Valentine's Day, social media users began speculating the suspect was undocumented.

description: In February 2017, President Trump repealed an Obama-era regulation that would have made it easier to block the sale of firearms to people with certain mental illnesses.

description: A youth baseball coach in Missouri said he wanted to make the giveaway "a positive thing."
title: Are Third-Graders Raffling Off an AR-15 After the Parkland Shooting?

description: Despite the clickbait caption, the video comes from East Texas, not Kensington Palace.

description: Despite conspiracy theorist speculation, no evidence supports a link between Nikolas Cruz and Islamic extremism.

description: A Mississippi YouTube user contacted law enforcement after a disturbing comment appeared on one of his videos.

description: Rumors that Nikolas Cruz was a registered Democrat were based on the voter registration of a different individual with a similar name and birth year.

description: The story is essentially true, but has picked up some embellishment along the way.

description: The rules for Kanesville Elementary's school dance attracted national attention before being "re-examined" by officials.

description: This claim is based on the incorrect interpretation of single quote from one nurse in Wisconsin who, for the record, recommends getting the shot.

description: An image purportedly showing an teacher with a gun slung across her back while watching over students is often shared with misleading claims about security protocols within the country.

description: Tamiflu is not responsible for the high number of flu season deaths, even if its potential rare side effects are scary.

description: Anti-Muslim blogger Pamela Geller posted an obvious fake and claimed it was an example of "migrant crime" in Europe.

description: A anti-Islam, anti-refugee video widely shared on Facebook was blatant fake news.
title: Did an American Teenager Who Killed a ‘Muslim Refugee’ for Raping His Sister Get 30 Years in Prison?

description: Dubious web sites attempted to paint the House Minority Leader as a hypocrite after her record-breaking eight-hour speech in support of DACA recipients.

description: Mars, Incorporated makes a "Pods" product, but these candies were first manufactured more than a decade before the "Tide Pod Challenge" went viral in 2018.

description: The 38-year-old's death from complications of influenza became an internet cause célèbre after it was rumored that she couldn't afford lifesaving medication.

description: A scurrilous fake news site took a controversial court case and added a fabricated element to it in order to produce clickbait.

description: Conspiracy theorists falsely linked a deadly Moscow plane crash to Uranium One, a debunked Hillary Clinton "scandal."

description: Shortly after a Trump senior aide resigned amid domestic abuse allegations, a false rumor was spread that the Vice President had defended his behavior.

description: Artist Kehinde Wiley is best known for reimagining classical heroic paintings using black men and women as his subjects.

description: An account posing as an ex-wife of former White House staff secretary Rob Porter, who resigned amid a domestic violence scandal, made the claim.

description: Social media users from Nigeria to New York City accused an unidentified man of being a taxi driver moonlighting as a serial killer.

description: The nature of a video posted to Chinese social media is unclear, but it may have been staged for an advertisement.

description: A meme targeting the Democratic lawmaker gets some, but not all, of the facts right.

description: Ashley Arnold attracted media attention after challenging — and triumphing over — her instructor's faulty grasp of geography.

description: A pair of articles about the legality of rape in police custody confused social media readers.

description: Internet users passed around an image that appeared to show river ice frozen in the shape of the mask worn by the Ghostface character in "Scream."

description: An image was digitally created after a construction tycoon was arrested for hunting in a protected sanctuary.

description: The white supremacist group made frequent use of the slogan more recently embraced by President Donald Trump, though they did not, as some claim, invent it.

description: The alleged trick of distracting a driver by cramming a plastic bottle in a wheel well runs counter to how most carjackers operate.

description: A series of images showing a Tesla Roadster looking down on earth from space are real.
title: Is This Car Really in Space?

description: Contrary to a fabricated tweet, the SpaceX CEO responded graciously to Trump's congratulations on the "American ingenuity" of the Falcon Heavy rocket.

description: The seeds of a number household plants can cause psychoactive effects, but they are far from a natural alternative to LSD, as popularly claimed.

description: A Twitter post painted Viktor and Amalija Knavs's immigration status as a symbol of hypocrisy on the part of the Trump administration.

description: Right-wing web sites republished a fabricated story posted by a notorious purveyor of fake news.
title: Did a Black Lives Matter Leader Get Sued for Embezzling Donations?

description: A Spirit customer claims that a Spirit employee told her to either flush her pet or set it free, a charge the airline denies.
title: Did Spirit Airlines Tell a Customer to Flush Her Hamster Down the Toilet?

description: Much ado was made on social media about the President's hair after a video aired of his boarding Air Force One on a windy day.

description: Two unrelated photographs were circulated on social media along with the a fictional story about actor Keanu Reeves' paying for stranger's kidney transplant.

description: An image purportedly showing a hermit crab using a human skull is actually a lifelike sculpture.

description: The fake news article misuses an image of a New York City building fire.

description: A "screening test" highlighted on the "Today Show" and subsequently amended by a series of dubious websites is actually pretty useless.

description: For once, a notorious purveyor of fake news gets some details right, but gets the overall story wrong.

description: Some of the images in a collage purporting to show the discovery of a "Goliath skeleton" date back to a 1993 tabloid article.

description: Rep. Adam Schiff, who authored a rebuttal to Devin Nunes's memo about the Trump-Russia investigation, is now the target of conspiracy theories and fake news.
title: Was Adam Schiff’s Sister Married to George Soros’s Son?

description: Facebook hasn't limited your feed to only a certain number of people, and sharing a post saying otherwise won't make any difference.
title: Does a New Facebook Algorithm Only Show You 26 Friends?

description: A viral Facebook post rehashed an old recall, causing hundreds of thousands of people unnecessary concern.
title: Safety Recall of Ventolin Inhalers?

description: A Facebook meme purporting to prove that the Dow suffers under Republican presidencies ignores key data.
title: Does the Dow Jones Do Worse Under Republican Presidents?

description: We found no evidence to suggest Costco toilet paper was any less safe for septic tanks than any other brand of bath tissue.
title: Is Costco Toilet Paper Unsafe for Plumbing Systems?

description: An Internet meme credits the Black Panther Party with inventing Women, Infants, and Children, a federal program that provides food assistance to impoverished mothers and children.

description: A spoof video about the notoriously anti-pot Attorney General was produced by a comedy group and managed to trick some viewers.

description: A popular meme showing a dog looking resentful as his owner poses with a significant other is based on a 2014 study suggesting dogs can behave jealously.

description: Students at Pennridge High School were asked to solve algebra formulas using vignettes from the difficult early life of Maya Angelou; Internet outrage ensued.

description: There is no evidence that the billionaire supporter of progressive causes ever uttered such a remark, or anything resembling it.

description: Banks' ordeal was turned into a meme that misrepresented key details of his case.

description: An incident that generated outrage on social media does not reflect company policy, according to the restaurant chain.
title: Did Outback Steakhouse Kick Out a Policeman Because it is a ‘Gun Free Zone’?

description: A former State Senate candidate says his Facebook account was hacked, and a series of troubling posts are the result of an attempt to sabotage his political career.
title: Did a Former Michigan Politician Defend Men Having Sex With Underage Girls?

description: An article claiming that a great white shark attacked a Greenpeace activist originated on a well-known fake news site.
title: Did a Greenpeace Activist Get His Arm Bitten Off After Hugging a Shark?

description: An image purportedly showing the official Twitter account for the Philadelphia Eagles telling President Trump to "go f*ck himself" is not real.

description: As Philadelphians destroyed their city in celebration, a ridiculous rumor took hold on social media.
title: Did an Eagles Fan Steal an Ostrich from the Zoo During Super Bowl Chaos?

description: In the wake of the decision to move the U.S. embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, a viral video has spread with a false claim.

description: A fake tweet attributed to President Donald Trump was meant to be a joke, but this is 2018.

description: The quote attributed to the famed actor was fabricated by a disreputable web site.
title: Did Denzel Washington Say Trump’s Election Saved Us From an ‘Orwellian Police State’?

description: A "celebrity feud" was actually a particularly lazy attempt at "outrage" clickbait.
title: Did Julia Roberts Tell Celine Dion ‘Go Back in Your Country’ If She Didn’t like Trump?

description: Images showing Nancy Pelosi pointing a finger at a Linda Sanchez are authentic, but a video of the event tells a different story.
title: Did Nancy Pelosi Scold a Democrat for Standing at the State of the Union Address?

description: U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley only inadvertently 'confessed' to being romantically involved with President Trump in clickbait headlines, not in her own words.

description: Official statistics suggest that some of the online retail giant's workforce receive food stamps, but it only applies to about 12 percent of one state's employees.
title: Do Amazon Employees Qualify for Food Stamps?

description: Rumors that there is a security wall outside the representative's Palm Beach House are inaccurate on several fronts.
title: Does Joe Kennedy’s Palm Beach House Have a Security Wall?

description: Conservatives and conspiracy theorists have made much of the fact that Luis Gutiérrez quietly walked out three minutes before the end of Trump's speech.
title: Did a Democratic Congressman ‘Storm Out’ of Trump’s State of the Union?

description: A Utah pediatrics practice says that Crayola bathtub fingerpaint soap caused caustic burns, but other users of the popular product didn't share that experience.
title: Crayola Bathtub Fingerpaint Soap Warning

description: Video footage shows an anti-immigration protester aggressively questioning Arizona state Rep. Eric Descheenie about his citizenship status.
title: Did Armed Trump Supporters Ask a Navajo Legislator If He’s ‘Legal’?

description: Unreliable web sites misrepresented the substance of the American Civil Liberties Union's critical response to President Trump's address.
title: Did the ACLU Complain That Trump Said ‘America’ Too Many Times in State of the Union?

description: A meme showing lawmakers checking their phones during the State of the Union is real — but this is not unprecedented, uncommon, or confined to one political party.
title: Did Democrats Check Their Phones During Trump’s State of the Union Address?

description: Some people actually believe in the medical misinformation they peddle; others shamelessly risk the public health by publishing erroneous medical info just for clicks and kicks.
title: Did Justin Timberlake Say ‘Mandatory Vaccination Schedules Are Un-American’?

description: The answer to the age-old question "Can peacocks fly?" is yes — but not on United Airlines.
title: Did United Airlines Deny a Passenger’s Request to Fly with an Emotional Support Peacock?

description: The prestigious university counts among its alumni Nobel laureates, leaders of science and industry, and a fleet of certified swashbucklers.
title: Does MIT Offer Students a ‘Pirate Certificate’?

description: The evangelical leader said in a 1981 profile that people in his position "can't be closely identified with any particular party or person."
title: Did Billy Graham Warn Against Mixing Religion and Politics?

description: An out-of-context video purportedly showing Jay-Z hitting a young fan has been circulating on the internet since the early 2000s.
title: Was Jay-Z Filmed Punching a 12-Year-Old Female Fan?

description: No evidence validates claims of foul play in a train crash involving Republican members of Congress.
title: Did a Train Carrying GOP Congressmen Crash Due to a ‘Deep State’ Plot?

description: Nope — a "satirical" web site just thinks misogyny is funny.
title: Will a Cooking, Cleaning Sex Robot Be Available by 2019?

description: The Food and Drug Administration has issued a draft guidance document suggesting a new legal interpretation of the controversial remedies, but they remain legal.
title: Are All Homeopathic Drugs Now Illegal?

description: If you donate to President Donald Trump’s campaign, your name will appear during a campaign-run livestream of his State of the Union address.
title: Will President Trump Display the Names of Campaign Donors During the State of the Union?

description: Foreign-born, U.S.-based scientists and economists won a remarkable number of Nobel prizes in the last two years, but they didn't get them all.
title: Did Immigrants Dominate the U.S. Nobel Prize Tally in 2016 and 2017?

description: A seemingly innocuous video shows neither a rat nor a shower.
title: Is This a Rat Showering Like a Person?

description: A photograph showing the former deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation with a group of armed officers is real, but it is not recent and does not show him being thrown or escorted out.
title: Did Security Escort Andrew McCabe Out of the FBI Building?

description: A well-known purveyor of fake news spread the fabricated claim that President Trump called out George Soros at the 2018 World Economic Forum.
title: Did Trump Tell George Soros to ‘Go to Hell’ at Davos?

description: A tasteless, body-shaming fake news article claimed that a hippopotamus attempted to rape a 400-pound woman after escaping from a Paris zoo.
title: Did a Woman Sue a Paris Zoo After an Escaped Hippo Tried to Rape Her?

description: Sitting senators tweeted images of the misspelled tickets on 29 January 2018.
title: Misspelled Tickets Issued for ‘State of the Uniom’ Address?

description: The Frenchman who would become known as the world's greatest pantomime artist helped smuggle Jewish children to safety in Switzerland during World War II.
title: Did Marcel Marceau Save Hundreds of Jewish Children From Nazis?

description: This year the hoaxes and fake news about a "rigged" Super Bowl started even before the game was played.
title: Was an NFL Lawyer Who Claimed the Super Bowl Is ‘Rigged’ Found Dead?

description: Gregory Salcido, who is also a City Council member in Pico Rivera, was caught on video making a series of controversial remarks about the armed services.
title: Did a California Teacher Call Military Members ‘the Lowest of Our Low’?

description: The "alpha" who purportedly flew the plane over the Women's March is entirely fictional —  but that didn't stop a legitimate news outlet from posting the image.
title: Did a Plane Fly a ‘Where’s My Damn Dinner?’ Banner Over the Women’s March?

description: The city of Melbourne tweeted that they do not endorse the sign, noting in a droll aside that they have no beaches in their municipality.
title: Does a ‘Multicultural Beach’ Sign in Melbourne Prohibit Pork and Alcohol?
